College of Environment & Safety Engineering, Fuzhou University No.2 Xueyuan Road, Shangjie Town, Minhou County Fuzhou Fujian 350116 China In this study, Cu was loaded on the surface of Ni-MOF by impregnation, and significantly improved the catalytic activity on lignin and its derivatives. The characterization showed that the non-noble bimetallic catalyst owned good dispersion, rich acid sites and stable structure was successfully synthesized. The introduced Cu reduced the reduction temperature of Ni, increased the acidity of the catalyst, and thus improved the catalytic performance and product selectivity of the catalyst. Under the mild conditions (120 °C), the conversion percentage of BPE was as high as 89.6 % using isopropyl alcohol as the hydrogen source. When the reaction temperature was 260 °C, the depolymerization percentage of corn cob lignin was 81.12 %, and the yield of phenol monomer could reach 11.46 wt. %. This work may provide an effective strategy for the preparation of efficient bimetallic catalysts for lignin hydrogenolysis. Graphical Abstract Synopsis: In this study, the Cu-Ni@C bimetallic catalyst was prepared using Ni-MOF as the support, which showed good catalytic performance for lignin model compounds and lignin under mild conditions. ga1 Keywords Lignin Lignin model compound Depolymerization MOF Cu-Ni@C catalyst Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The high-quality utilization of biomass and its derivatives is an effective way to reduce the energy crisis and solve environmental problems [1,2]. As the second largest component of biomass, lignin contributes about 40 % of the energy and has great potential for conversion into value-added chemicals and liquid fuels [3]. Lignin is the most significant component of biomass and the primary renewable aromatic source, which is a three-dimensional biopolymer composed of p-coumarin, coniferyl alcohol and sinapyl alcohol, the chemical bonds include α-O- 4, β- O- 4, 4-HO-5, etc [4,5]. Finding an effective method to break these carbon-oxygen bonds is crucial for producing various polymers, fuels, and other chemicals from lignin. There are many methods to depolymerize lignin, among which hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is a potential process to remove oxygen by changing the carbon-oxygen chain, carbon-oxygen chain, and carbon-carbon chain through high hydrogen pressure to improve energy density and fuel stability, and is one of the most popular and efficient methods for lignin depolymerization [6,7]. There are many catalysts for lignin hydrodeoxygenation, and the common ones are mono-metallic and bimetallic catalysts [8]. Compared with monometallic catalyst, metal promoters can improve the catalyst surface properties and active site dispersion and improve the stability of the catalyst in the harsher conditions [9,10]. Therefore, the activity, selectivity and stability of the bimetal catalyst for lignin hydrogenation are higher than those of the mono-metal catalyst. Precious metals are widely used in lignin hydrogenolysis due to their excellent ability of adsorbing and dissociating hydrogen, such as Pt-Ru [11], Ni-Pd [12] and Ru-Ni [13] etc. However, the high cost of precious metals and their easy deactivation at high temperature limit their commercial application. Therefore, it is particularly important to develop cheap and efficient non-precious bimetallic catalysts. There are many combinations of non-noble bimetals, among which Cu-Ni bimetallic catalysts have been widely concerned due to their reasonable price and excellent catalytic activity. For example, Lu et al. [14] studied a series of cheap nickel-based bimetallic catalysts (Ni/(Fe/Zn/Co/Mo/Cu) -WO3 /Al2O3) for hydrogenation and depolymerization of alkali lignin. The results showed that the catalytic performance of dual-promoted Ni/X-WO3/Al2O3 catalyst was significantly better than that of single Ni catalyst. The doped Ni promotes the cleavage of ether bonds, which in turn promotes the hydrogenation and demethylation of monomers. Kong et al. [15] prepared Ni-Cu-HZSM-5 catalyst by loading Cu on HZSM-5 for hydrogenation of aromatic aldehydes. It was found that doping Cu element could inhibit excessive hydrogenation and improve the selectivity of the products. Although most studies have shown that the bimetallic catalysts had good catalytic activity and product selectivity in lignin hydrogenolysis, non-noble metal catalysts prepared by traditional carriers still have some disadvantages such as uncontrollable structure, low loading and easy deactivation. In previous studies, MOF has been widely used in catalysis, hydrogen storage and drug carrier [16,17]. MOFs have different structures, compositions, homogeneous pores, and high surface areas compared to conventional microporous and mesoporous materials [18,19]. Cai et al. [20] impregnated Pd and Ni with MIL-100(Fe) as support to prepare bimetallic catalyst, which had good catalytic activity. Pd1Ni4/MIL-100(Fe) catalysts could have good structural stability during the reaction and showed high activity in all five cycles. Zhu et al. [21] compared the performance of MOF based Ni/C and NiCo/C catalysts, and proved that Co and Ni can form an alloy structure, produce a synergistic catalytic effect, and greatly improve the catalytic activity of lignin depolymerization. Dou et al. [22]. successfully synthesized porous hollow Ni-Fe (H-NiFe2O4) catalysts by calcining Prussian blue (PB) crystals wrapped with Ni(CH3COO)2 on the surface layer, the catalyst retained the hollow cubic structure of the parent PB and improved the dispersion of the metal nanoparticles. Based on the characteristics of MOF, we envisaged whether Mof can be used as the precursor to overcome the defects of traditional support and prepare high performance Ni-Cu catalyst. In our previous work, the Ni@C catalyst prepared with Ni-MOF as a precursor showed excellent hydrogenolysis performance for lignin model compounds at 160 °C with isopropyl alcohol as hydrogen source [23]. Therefore, we proposed to introduce the second metal into the Ni-MOF precursor by different methods, and successfully prepared a variety of bimetallic catalysts, among which the Ni-Cu@C catalyst prepared by impregnating Cu supported by Cu had the highest catalytic activity. In addition, the performance of the catalyst and the effects of Cu loading, temperature and solvent were studied, and the lignin degradation products were characterized. The results showed that the catalyst exhibited good hydrogenation activity for both lignin model compounds and actual lignin under mild conditions without external pressure. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials The corn cob lignin used in this study was obtained from Shandong Longevity Biotechnology Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). Chemicals like terephthalic acid, nickel nitrate and benzyl phenyl ether etc. were obtained from Beijing Aladdin Chemical Co., Ltd (Beijing, China). Solvents like methanol and isopropanol etc. were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). 2.2 Preparation of the catalysts 2.2.1 Preparation of bimetallic catalysts by bimetallic-centered MOF precursors MOF carbon-based catalysts centered on different bimetals were prepared by co-doping. 1.14 g Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.28 g metal salts (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, FeCl3·6H2O, ZnNO3·6H2O, Co(NO3)2·6H2O) were dissolved into 25 mL N, N-dimethylformamide and the solution was sonicated for 15 min until completely dissolved. Then 0.55 g of terephthalic acid was dissolved in another 25 mL of N, N-dimethylformamide. After mixing and stirring the above two solutions, transfer them to a 50 mL Teflon autoclave. The precursor M/Ni-MOF (M is Fe, Zn, Co, or Cu) was obtained by removing the residual solvent from the material was dried at 80 °C for 12 h. Finally, 1.0 g of dried M/Ni-MOF was weighed into a fixed-bed quartz tube and pre-gassed with 5 vol. % H2 /Ar for 40 min to expel the air from the quartz glass tube by a temperature increase to 500 °C at 10 °C/min for 300 min. The obtained catalyst M/Ni@C was collected after cooling to room temperature. 2.2.2 Preparation of bimetallic catalysts by Ni-MOF carrier impregnation A bimetallic carbon-based catalyst was prepared by impregnating the second metal with Ni-MOF as the support. 1.14 g of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved into 20 mL of N, N-dimethylformamide with sonication for 15 min. Then, 0.44 g of terephthalic acid was dissolved in the solution under same operation. After that, the above solution was mixed and transferred to an autoclave, and the reaction was carried out at 150 °C for 24 h before cooling to room temperature. When the autoclave was cooled down, the final material was obtained after washing with N, N-dimethylformamide and methanol three times, and was dried at 80 °C for 12 h. The metal salts (FeCl3·6 H2O, ZnNO3·6 H2O, Co(NO3)2·6 H2O, Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O) were weighed and fully dissolved in 20 mL of methanol solvent, followed by adding 1.0 g of Ni-MOF prepared in the previous step and impregnated with sufficient stirring for 24 h, followed by vacuum drying at 80 °C for 10 h to obtain the precursor Mx-Ni-MOF (for M as Fe, Zn, Co or Cu). The catalyst is consistent with the M/Ni-MOF pyrolysis method described above. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The crystal structure of the catalyst was investigated using an X-ray diffractometer (MiniFlex600, Ritani, Japan) at room temperature and pressure, Cu Kα-ray source, 40 mA, 40 kV, the scan range of 10–80°. Scanning electron microscopy was used to describe the catalysts' morphological and structural features (Verios G4 UC, FEI, USA). The nitrogen adsorption-desorption test analyzed the material's specific surface area and pore structure. The surface acidity of the prepared catalysts was tested using NH3 -Programmed temperature desorption (AutoChem1 II 2920, BelCata II, Japan). The surface acidity was tested by weighing an appropriate amount of sample in a reaction tube, pre-treating with a programmed ramp-up from room temperature to 200 °C, then purging with a He gas stream for 1 h, cooling the material to 50 °C, passing a 10 vol. % NH3/He mixture for 1 h to saturate the adsorption, and then switching to a He gas stream for 1 h to remove the surface weakness. The surface of the weakly physically adsorbed NH was removed3 by purging for 1 h, and finally, the material was desorbed under He atmosphere, TCD detected the desorbed gas. 2.4 Depolymerization of lignin model compounds The depolymerization of lignin model compounds was in a 50 mL stainless steel reactor with polystyrene (PPL) as the membrane. In a typical process, 40 mg of the above prepared bimetallic catalyst and 0.4 mmol of lignin model compound were added in a 50 mL reaction kettle, and then 20 mL of isopropanol was added. After sonication for 10 min, the reactants were completely dissolved, and nitrogen was used to purge out the residual air in the reaction kettle. After sealing, the hydrothermal reaction kettle is placed in the air drying oven and heated to the set temperature for 300 min. After the reaction is completed, the material is discharged after cooling to room temperature. All reactions were repeated at least three times. 2.5 Disaggregation of actual lignin The depolymerization of lignin was in a 50 mL autoclave. In a typical process, 100 mg of the above prepared bimetallic catalyst and 500 mg of corn cob enzymatic lignin were weighed in a 50 mL reaction kettle, then the mixture was completely dissolved by introducing 20 mL isopropanol. The residual air was purged out of the kettle using nitrogen gas, and then the hydrothermal reaction kettle was sealed and in the oven to 260 °C and hold for 300 min. The specific depolymerization and product separation process are shown in Fig S1. Lignin conversion (X) and yield of monophenolic compounds (Y) were calculated as follows: X= (m0 - m1) / m0) × 100 % Y= (m2 / m0) × 100 % m0: initial dosage of lignin; m1: residual amount of lignin; m2: quality of monophenols. 2.6 Analysis of lignin degradation products The depolymerization percentage of the model compounds and the phenol yield were detected by high-performance liquid chromatography (Shimadzu LC-20AT). 0.2 mL of liquid was measured from the depolymerization product of the model compound and diluted 50 times. Subsequently, 1.5 mL of the diluted solution was measured to a sample vial for awaiting analysis. The residual amount of substrate and phenol content of samples were calculated according to the standard curve. The composition and yield of lignin and model compounds depolymerization products were detected by a gas chromatography coupled (GC-MS, Agilent6890–59731, USA). The reaction solvent was removed by rotary evaporation at 50 °C, followed by the addition of ethyl acetate to dissolve the solution fully, and acetophenone solution with known concentration was used as internal standard for machine detection. Fourier infrared spectrometry was used to characterize the original lignin with the depolymerized residual lignin, scanning 32 times in the scan range of 400–4000 cm−1. NMR spectroscopy was used to characterize the original lignin and the depolymerized product bio-oil. 20 mg of the original lignin was dissolved with the depolymerization product bio-oil in 1 mL of deuterated dimethyl sulfoxide, and the reference material was tetramethylsiloxane. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Evaluation of the catalytic activity of bimetallic catalysts First of all, for benzyl phenyl ether (BPE), the catalytic activity of bimetallic catalysts Fe/Ni@C, Zn/Ni@C, Co/Ni@C, and Cu/Ni@C were examined. In our previous work, it was found that the monometallic catalyst Ni@C showed a depolymerization percentage of 90.20 % for BPE at 150 °C and 41.62 % at 140 °C [23]. Therefore, 140 °C was selected as the reaction condition to screen the prepared bimetallic catalysts ( Table 1, entry 1). As seen from Table 1, the depolymerization percentages of Fe/Ni@C, Zn/Ni@C, Co/Ni@C, and Cu/Ni@C for BPE at 140 °C were all lower than 5 %. Compared with the monometallic catalyst Ni@C-650, the depolymerization efficiency was significantly low. The reason for this phenomenon is mainly that in this reaction system, nickel is the active reaction center, which both activates the solvent to produce hydrogen for the subsequent reaction and also provides the active site for the following hydrodeoxygenation. Therefore, the content and morphology of nickel are crucial for the catalytic reactivity. In synthesizing bimetallic-centered MOF, combining the metal center with the organic ligand is uncontrollable. The content of active center nickel in the bimetallic carbon-based catalysts prepared with bimetallic-centered MOF as the precursor is lower than Ni@C. During calcination, the active center of nickel was covered by the laden metal, so the catalytic reactivity was low. Based on this, the precursors Fe-Ni-MOF, Zn-Ni-MOF, Co-Ni-MOF, and Cu-Ni-MOF were obtained by impregnating different metal ions (Fe3+, Zn2+, Co2+, Cu2+) with Ni-MOF as the carrier to guarantee the morphology and content of nickel in the synthesized catalysts. The activity of bimetallic catalyst prepared by impregnation method was studied at 140 °C. As can be seen from the table, except for 0.2Zn-Ni@C, the catalytic activity of 0.2 Fe-Ni@C, 0.2Co-Ni@C, and 0.2Cu-Ni@C all have a great improvement, and the highest catalytic activity occurred to 0.2Cu-Ni@C. At 140 °C, the depolymerization percentage of BPE increased by 54.01 %, and the phenol yield increased by 55.4 wt. %. The introduction of Cu improved the performance of the catalyst during hydrodeoxygenation, probably because Cu formed an alloy with Ni, thus enhancing the influence of electrons on the catalyst activity [24,25]. According to the electronic band theory, Cu has free delectrons, In contrast, the group VIII metal Ni has off-domain free d orbitals in the conduction band, the interaction between the two metals may lead to the filling of the d region of the Ni species, thus the adsorption strength of the catalyst is reduced compared to that of a single Ni material [26]. Ni metal atom in the catalyst is the adsorption and active site in the reaction, and Ni can adsorb active hydrogen, while Cu has no obvious adsorption effect on active hydrogen. According to the catalytic theory, the catalyst with appropriately reduced adsorption strength had higher catalytic activity [27]. Therefore, when the appropriate amount of Cu was introduced, the absorption strength of the catalyst for active hydrogen were weakened, and the yield and migration rate of active hydrogen was increased, thus promoting the hydrogenation reaction. According to previous studies, the synergistic effect of Cu and Ni is beneficial to improving the selectivity of monophenolic compounds in the products. Therefore, the introduced Cu could improve the activity for the depolymerization of BPE in addition to inhibiting the over-hydrogenation of the product, and the yield of phenol in the product of the reaction was maintained at a high level, reaching 89.65 wt. %. According to the experimental results, the performance of the bimetallic catalysts obtained after loading Fe, Co and Cu by the impregnation method was improved in comparison to the single metal Ni@C catalysts, especially the introduction of Cu showed the highest performance. The depolymerization percentage of benzyl phenyl ether increased from 41.62 % to 95.63 % at the reaction temperature of 140 °C, and it also showed excellent performance in inhibiting the over hydrogenation also showed excellent performance. 3.2 Characterization of the obtained catalysts Fig. 1 showed the XRD spectra of 0.10Cu-Ni@C, 0.15Cu-Ni@C, 0.20Cu-Ni@C, and 0.25Cu-Ni@C materials obtained at same calcination temperatures. The figure showed three distinctive peaks can be observed at 44.6°, 51.8°, and 76.3° in the spectra of Cu-Ni@C, which were (111), (200), and (220) crystal planes of Ni, respectively. The characteristic diffraction peaks attributed to Cu (43.3°, 50.5°, 74.1°) were not observed. The main reason for this is that the good pore volume and excellent specific surface area of Ni-MOF when Ni-MOF is used as the impregnating carrier, which facilitates the high dispersion of the doped Cu metal on the carrier [28,29]. Compared with the XRD spectra of Ni@C catalysts, the characteristic diffraction peaks attributed to NiO at 37.3° and 62.8° disappeared after the introduction of Cu, which was mainly due to the synergistic effect between Cu and Ni that lowered the reduction temperature of NiO, resulting in the reduction of NiO to Ni [30]. The SEM images ( Fig. 2.a-e) showed Ni@C-650 and Cu-Ni@C catalysts (0.10Cu-Ni@C, 0.15Cu-Ni@C, 0.20Cu-Ni@C, and 0.25Cu-Ni@C). Ni@C-650 is a material with a rough surface and with protruding spherical shell structure with partial structural collapse. The morphological structure of the Cu-Ni@C catalysts is similar to Ni@C-650, which is a hollow spherical shell structure with a protruding surface. And as the amount of Cu dosage increased, the surface gradually became smoother and a flocculent structure developed there, but the original spherical shell shape was preserved. This is mainly because original carrier structure can be maintained when the second metal is loaded by the impregnation method. The signal of Cu appeared in EDS mapping images of 0.15Cu-Ni@C, and the loaded Cu was well dispersed on the catalyst surface, and no apparent accumulation was observed (Fig. 2.f-g). In addition, the normalized mass of Ni in 0.15Cu-Ni@C prepared by the impregnation method was 45.18 %, indicating that the nickel is highly dispersed and the synergistic effect generated by Cu doping can enhance the reaction activity. The BET analysis results show that the catalyst's specific surface area, pore volume and diameter changed with a further increase in doped copper ( Table2). The surface area of the undoped catalyst Ni@C is 114.5 m2/g, the pore volume is 0.38 cm3/g, and the pore diameter is 13.25 nm (Table 2, entry 1). And the specific surface area, pore volume and pore of the Cu-doped catalyst 0.10Cu-Ni@C decreased to 67.26 m2 /g, 0.20 cm3/g and 11.91 nm, respectively (Table 2, entry 2). This is mainly because Cu tends to agglomerate when the calcination temperature is higher than 200 °C. When the calcination temperature was 500 °C, the Cu impregnated in Ni-MOF would agglomerate in the pore channel and block the pore channel, which led to the decrease of the specific surface area and pore size of the catalyst. As the impregnation amount increases, more Cu agglomerates in the pore channel., the specific surface area and pore size of the catalyst decreased further, so the specific surface area of 0.25Cu-Ni@C was the lowest (26.66 m2 /g). To investigate the effect of Cu dosage on the acidic site distribution and acidity of the catalysts, temperature programmed using ammonia chemical adsorption apparatus of different doping amounts of catalyst 0.10Cu-Ni@C, 0.15Cu-Ni@C, 0.20Cu-Ni@C and 0.25Cu-Ni@C have been characterized ( Table 3). Firstly, at the same calcination temperature, two single metal catalysts (Ni@C-500 and 0.15Cu-Ni@C) were first examined for their distribution and acidity of acidic sites. Ni@C-500 was 1.03 mmol/g and 38.09 mmol/g, respectively, at 321.3 °C and 427.8 °C. After doping Cu, the two acidic sites of the catalyst were distributed at 351.0 °C and 449.7 °C, and the acidity was 0.43 mmol/g and 52.14 mmol/g. The acidic sites of 0.15Cu-Ni@C were concentrated in the medium acid sites, and the acidity also increased significantly from 38.09 to 52.14 mmol/g. The great medium acidic sites benefit the catalyst's activation of free hydrogen ions and promote the breakage of lignin C-O ether bonds. It can be seen by comparison that with the increase in doping amount, the acidity increases first and then decreases. This was mainly due to the existence of unsaturated metal ions, which could acted as a new L acid center after Cu doping, making up for and exceeding the number of B acid sites covered by it. With the further increase of Cu doping amount, the new acid sites cannot make up for the acid sites covered, resulting in the decrease of the acidity of the catalyst. 3.3 Effect of reaction temperature on BPE depolymerization In subsection 3.1, it was found that the introduction of Cu could effectively reduce the reaction temperature of the catalyst for the model compound and improve the catalytic activity. To further investigate the effect of cu doping on the catalyst, the catalytic activity of 0.2Cu-Ni@C for BPE at different temperatures was investigated ( Fig. 3.a). As seen in figure, the conversion percentage of BPE was only 18.3 % at 100 °C. When the reaction temperature increased to 120 °C, the BPE depolymerization percentage reached 73.8 %. As the temperature goes up to 150 °C, the BPE depolymerization percentage reached 100 %. It was seen from the experimental results that the catalyst showed a significant improvement in the conversion percentage to the model compounds after the introduction of Cu, which is consistent with the results reported in the literature that the introduction of Cu can improve the performance of the catalyst for catalytic hydrogenation of lignin and its derivatives [31]. In addition, the introduction of Cu showed excellent performance in inhibiting the further hydrogenation of the products compared to the single Ni-based catalyst Ni@C. Meanwhile, the phenol yield also showed an increasing trend as the reaction temperature increased and reached 95.8 wt. % when the reaction temperature was 150 °C. This was mainly because Cu doping facilitated the change of the adsorption state of the molecules on the metal surface, which improved the HDO activity and inhibited the excessive hydrogenation. 3.4 Effect of Cu doping amount on the hydrodeoxygenation reaction of BPE In the previous subsection, it can be found that the depolymerization percentage of the catalyst for BPE is as high as 100 % when the reaction temperature is 150 °C(Fig. 3.a). Based on this, in this subsection, the reactivity of catalysts with different copper doping amounts 0.10Cu-Ni@C, 0.15Cu-Ni@C, 0.20Cu-Ni@C, and 0.25Cu-Ni@C was investigated using 120 °C as the reaction temperature to optimize. Fig. 3.b show that the performance of the catalysts with varying degrees of Cu doping was enhanced above that of the original Ni@C. With the increase of Cu doping, the performance of the catalyst first increases and then decreases. The catalytic performance of 0.15Cu-Ni@C was the best, with the depolymerization percentage of BPE up to 89.6 % and the phenol yield up to 86.0 wt. % at a reaction temperature of 120 °C. This is mainly because the introduction of Cu not only allows more Ni atoms to be exposed on the catalyst surface but also modulates the adsorption strength of the catalyst. And with the increase of Cu introduction, more Cu reduction will further reduce the catalytic specific surface area, and the undissolved Cu particles may cover the active sites of Ni, thus decreasing the catalytic activity, which is consistent with the results reported for other bimetallic catalysts [32,33]. 3.5 Effect of reaction solvent on the hydrodeoxygenation reaction of BPE To compare the catalytic effect of the catalysts in different reaction solvents after the introduction of Cu, 0.15Cu-Ni@C was tested for its catalytic BPE hydrodeoxygenation activity in other solvents. Fig. 3.c show that after the introduction of Cu, the catalytic efficiency in different solvents was improved compared to the monometallic catalyst Ni@C-650. However, the type of solvent still plays a decisive role in the reactivity in this reaction system. When the solvents were methanol, ethanol, n-propanol, and propanetriol, the reactivity was low, and the depolymerization percentage of BPE was below 10 %. However, when the solvent was isopropanol, the depolymerization percentage of BPE increased to 89.6 %. This is mainly because although the introduction of copper can ascension the catalytic activity of the catalyst in the reaction system without an external hydrogen source, the hydrogen source required for the subsequent hydrodeoxygenation reaction is all provided by the solvent. The poor dehydrogenation ability of methanol, ethanol, n-propanol, and propanetriol cannot offer sufficient hydrogen sources for the subsequent reaction, thus limiting the activity of the following reaction. In contrast, when isopropanol is used as the solvent, Ni in the catalyst can separate the hydrogen ions on the hydroxyl groups of isopropanol and activate them into active hydrogen. Under this premise, BPE was depolymerized into phenol and toluene based on the synergistic interaction between Cu and Ni. 3.6 Catalytic effects of catalysts for model compounds with different bond types Different models of compound bond energy intensity is different. The catalytic activities of three model compounds with different bond types, phenyl phenyl ether (BPE), phenoxyethyl benzene (PPE) and diphenyl ether (DPE), were investigated at 160 °, which was higher than the optimal degradation temperature of BPE, using 0.15Cu-Ni@C as catalyst. It can be seen from Fig. 3.d that the catalysts achieved 100 %, 94.3 %, and 91.2 % depolymerization of benzyl phenyl ether, phenoxy ethylbenzene, and diphenyl ether, respectively, at the reaction temperature of 160 °C, where the phenol yields were 96.5 wt. %, 92.9 wt. %, and 90.0 wt. %. The results showed that the catalysts also showed significant improvement in catalytic depolymerization performance for model compounds with different bond types after doping with Cu. 3.7 Effect of Cu-Ni@C catalyst for catalytic depolymerization of lignin The previous experiments demonstrated that the catalytic depolymerization effect of the Cu-Ni@C catalyst was significantly higher for lignin model compounds compared to the monometallic catalyst Ni@C. To further investigate the practical application of Cu-Ni@C catalyst in depolymerizing lignin, the catalytic depolymerization effect of the catalyst 0.15Cu-Ni@C on the enzymatic depolymerization of lignin from corn cob was investigated by using isopropyl alcohol as the reaction solvent and reacting at a reaction temperature of 260 °C for 5 h. T Compared with the blank group without the addition of catalyst, the lignin depolymerization percentage increased from 64.94 % to 81.12 % after adding 0.15Cu-Ni@C. Compared with previous studies on lignin hydrogenolysis, 0.15Cu-Ni@C still had excellent catalytic activity in corn cob for lignin depolymerization without pressure, and the catalytic efficiency was much higher than that of traditional bimetallic catalystsas summarized in Table S1 [34–38]. 3.7.1 FT-IR analysis To investigate the structural changes of lignin before and after depolymerization, FT-IR characterization of the depolymerized residual lignin without the addition of catalyst and after the addition of 0.15Cu-Ni@C catalyst was performed, respectively. Fig. 4 show the FT-IR spectra of lignin before and after depolymerization after the addition of catalyst. It was clear from the statistics that the FT-IR spectra of the residual lignin depolymerized by the introduction of catalyst changed obviously, with the intensity of the characteristic peaks at various positions weakening significantly (Fig. 4.c). The distinct peaks in the spectrum at 3500–3300 cm−1 are due to the hydroxyl vibrations on the phenolic and alcohol hydroxyl groups, where the intensity of the residual lignin after depolymerization by 0.15 Cu-Ni@C is significantly weakened, indicating the formation of compounds with phenolic hydroxyl structures in the depolymerization products. The spectrum's characteristic peaks at 2925 cm−1 and 2835 cm−1 correspond to the lignin methoxy and methyl vibrations, respectively. [39]. The signal of the residual lignin changed significantly after depolymerization, indicating that dealkylation and demethoxylation occurred during the depolymerization process. Meanwhile, at 1710 cm−1, the CO stretching vibration in the non-conjugated ketone, carbonyl, and ester groups, the weakening of the signal peak indicates that the CO bond is broken during the depolymerization process. The signal peaks at 1608 cm−1 and 1501 cm−1, and 1420 cm−1 are characteristic of the aromatic hydrocarbon backbone. The residual lignin signal here indicates that the lignin retains its original aromatic ring structure after depolymerization. 1214 cm−1 and 1113 cm−1 are characteristic of the C-O ether bond in the lignin structure, and the weakening of the signal peak here indicates that the CO bond is broken during depolymerization. The signal at 1164 cm−1 is attributed to the CO stretching vibration peak on the H-unit. The disappearance of the movement in the depolymerization residue indicates that many H-units on the lignin structure were shed during the depolymerization process. 3.7.2 Gas chromatography/mass spectrometry coupled analysis The depolymerization products were qualitative and quantitative analyzed using GC-MS, and the results are shown in Table 4. The yield of phenolic monomers increased from 5.27 wt. % to 11.46 wt. % after adding 0.15Cu-Ni@C compared to no catalyst added. Compared with the monometallic catalyst Ni@C-650, the introduction of Cu further improved the depolymerization efficiency, and the phenolic monomer yield increased from 9.63 wt. % to 11.46 wt. %. The highest results of the products were 4-ethylphenol and 4-ethyl-2-methoxyphenyl, which increased from 4.16 wt. % and 3.41–5.53 wt. % and 3.68 wt. %. These two products accounted for 48.25 % and 32.11 % of the total phenolic products. GC-MS Characterization further proved that the introduction of copper improved the lignin depolymerization efficiency and promoted the conversion of lignin to small molecule compounds. 3.7.3 2D-HSQC characterization analysis To further investigate the changes among lignin structural units after depolymerization via 0.15Cu-Ni@C, two-dimensional NMR hydrogen spectrum was used to characterize the original lignin and the depolymerization product bio-oil, and the obtained 2D-HSQC spectra are shown in Fig. 5. The Aα, Aβ and Aγ signals attributed to β-O-4 in the bio-oil disappeared with the signs attributed to the β-β bond and α-O-4 bond, which surface that the β-O-4 bond, β-β bond, and α-O-4 in the lignin structure were successfully broken (Fig. 5.a-b). It can be seen that the PCA signals attributable to the structural portion of the H-unit of lignin in bio-oil vanished by comparing the HSQC spectra(Fig. 5.c-d). The signals attributed to the G-unit and S-unit were significantly weakened compared with the original lignin, indicating that the H-unit of lignin was the central unit converted during the depolymerization process, while the G-unit and S-unit were also partially restored. 3.8 Catalyst reuse performance testing Table 5 showed the recovery and reuse experiments results for 0.15Cu-Ni@C at 120 °C. Although Cu was introduced, the metal in the catalyst was still mainly Ni, so the catalyst still had good magnetic properties and could be quickly recovered from the solution under an applied magnetic field. As can be seen from Table 5, the conversion percentage and recovery percentage of BPE decreased with the increase of the use times, but both remained above 70 %, indicating that the catalyst had good stability. It can be seen from the SEM images after the catalyst is used (Fig.S2.) that there was no significant change after the catalyst was used once, and the overall morphology and structure of the catalyst were basically unchanged after four times of use, but there was agglomeration and slight breakage, which is one of the reasons for the decrease of catalyst activity. 4 Conclusions In this work, we tried to use Ni-MOF as the carrier to prepare Cu-Ni@C non-noble metal catalyst, which overcame some defects existing in the traditional carrier, improved the performance of the catalyst, and reduced the reaction conditions. When the reaction temperature was only 120 °C and no external hydrogen source was added, for benzyl phenyl ether depolymerization percentage reached 89.6 %, phenol yield reached 86.0 wt. %. In addition, the catalyst was also suitable for actual lignin without external pressure, the lignin depolymerization percentage reached 81.16 % at 260 °C depolymerization temperature，and the phenolic monomer yield was 11.46 wt. %. The selectivity of 4-ethylphenol and 4-ethyl-2-methoxyphenol was up to 48.25 % and 32.11 %, respectively. Overall, this study provides insights into the preparation of efficient bimetallic catalysts and the selective hydrogenation and depolymerization of lignin under mild conditions. coredata.dc:description: In this study, Cu was loaded on the surface of Ni-MOF by impregnation, and significantly improved the catalytic activity on lignin and its derivatives. The characterization showed that the non-noble bimetallic catalyst owned good dispersion, rich acid sites and stable structure was successfully synthesized. The introduced Cu reduced the reduction temperature of Ni, increased the acidity of the catalyst, and thus improved the catalytic performance and product selectivity of the catalyst. Under the mild conditions (120 °C), the conversion percentage of BPE was as high as 89.6 % using isopropyl alcohol as the hydrogen source. When the reaction temperature was 260 °C, the depolymerization percentage of corn cob lignin was 81.12 %, and the yield of phenol monomer could reach 11.46 wt. %. This work may provide an effective strategy for the preparation of efficient bimetallic catalysts for lignin hydrogenolysis.
coredata.dc:title: High-performance depolymerization of lignin by bimetallic Cu-Ni@C catalysts prepared with MOF as a carrier under mild conditions
